sentences.english: Abundance One of the most common human fears is scarcity.
sentences.chinese: 知足常樂貧窮是人類最普遍的恐懼之一。

sentences.english: Hi is the richest who is content with the least, for content is the wealth of nature.
sentences.chinese: 知足常樂者最富有，因爲知足本身就是財富。

sentences.english: He is richest who is content with the least, for content is the wealth of nature.
sentences.chinese: 知足常樂者最富有，因爲知足本身就是天然的財富。

sentences.english: The happiest people are those who are contented with what they currently have, not with what they lack.
sentences.chinese: 最快樂的那些人總是會知足常樂，而不會傷懷所缺的。

sentences.english: In other words, they count their blessings .
sentences.chinese: 換句話說，他們知足常樂。

sentences.english: Let's just let ourselves be happy and satistied.
sentences.chinese: 就讓我們知足常樂，無憾的欣賞。

sentences.english: They simply learnt to be satisfied with their lot .
sentences.chinese: 他們只是懂得知足常樂罷了。

sentences.english: Life will rock if you realize you’re already doing the best thing ever.
sentences.chinese: 如果你懂得知足常樂，那麼你的生活將充滿驚喜。

sentences.english: But more importantly, they are about achieving contentment.
sentences.chinese: 但更爲重要的是要懂得知足常樂。

sentences.english: They needed to learn the lesson of abundance.
sentences.chinese: 其實，他們就需要學會知足常樂這一課。

sentences.english: First optimistic attitude to life, contentment.
sentences.chinese: 首先要樂天知命，知足常樂。

sentences.english: Are you an easily satisfied man?
sentences.chinese: 你是個知足常樂的人嗎？

definition: at home wherever one is (idiom); ready to adapt/flexible/to accept circumstances with good will
receptive as an echoing canyon (idiom); modest and open-minded
tranquility yields transcendence (idiom); quiet life of profound study/cf Still waters run deep.
to put oneself in sb else's shoes (idiom)
to resign oneself to adversity (idiom); to grin and bear it/to submit meekly to insults, maltreatment, humiliation etc
having ample food and clothing (idiom); well fed and clothed
everything is going smoothly/just as one wishes
to enjoy the present (idiom); to live happily with no thought for the future/make merry while you can/carpe diem
lit. firewood, rice, oil, salt, soy, vinegar, and tea/fig. life's daily necessities
pinyin: chai2 mi3 you2 yan2 jiang4 cu4 cha2

definition: to have one's feet firmly planted on the ground (idiom); realistic without flights of fancy/steady and serious character
